ygData.subject: Re: ChemEquil problems
ygData.msgSnippet: If I solve the equilibrium problem using a speficied temperature, I am able to solve it easily for the entire range of enthalpies that I wish to cover.

Subject: Re: ChemEquil problems
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=222940872
X-Yahoo-Profile: jcs6a50
X-eGroups-Approved-By: dggoodwin <dgoodwin@...> via web; 13 May 2005 21:46:45 -0000

If I solve the equilibrium problem using a speficied temperature, I am
able to solve it easily for the entire range of enthalpies that I wish
to cover.

However, what I would really like is to specify pressure and enthalpy
and solve the problem, rather than having to specify pressure and
temperature interpolate results to the enthalpy that is needed.

I could use the TP mode to get a good guess for the HP solution,
however.  Are there any plans to activate the "contin" option to allow
a good initial guess to be passed through to the equilibrium solver?

If not, I will just interpolate the TP results...

Thanks,

James

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "jcs6a50" <jnsuthe@s...> wrote:
> The temperatures at which failure occur are not necessarily below
the
> polynomial fit ranges; in that case, I understand that there may be
> problems.  I am using the setState_HP method to fix the enthalpy,
and
> perform the calculation at successively lower enthalpies.
> 
> One thing that could be very useful is to implement the "contin"
> option that would allow a better initial guess for the equilibrium
> state to be provided.  Are there plans to do this in the near
future?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> James
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> > I haven't run into this problem before. I suppose you're
decreasing
> the 
> > enthalpy by calling 'setState_HP' first with the desired enthalpy
> and 
> > pressure and initial composition.  I bet the problem is that the 
> > resulting initial temperature is so low that it is either out of
> range 
> > for the thermo data, or causes numerical problems for other
reasons.
> > 
> > Can you run the problem fixing (T,P) rather than (H,P)?
> > 
> > You might also try the new equilibrium solver, which doesn't use 
> > ChemEquil.  In Python, you can access it by creating a 'Mixture' 
> > containing the gas phase:
> > 
> > gas = GRI30()
> > mix = Mixture([(gas, 1.0)])
> > mix.equilibrate('HP')
> > print mix
> > 
> > And if you want to include a condensed phase, you can do it like
> this:
> > gas = GRI30()
> > carbon = importPhase('graphite.cti')
> > mix = Mixture([(gas, 1.0), (carbon, 0.0)])
> > mix.equilibrate('HP')
> > print mix
> > 
> > Depending on the version of Cantera you have this may or may not
> work.  
> > It definitely works with the prerelease of version 1.6, available
> by 
> > CVS.
> > 
> > Dave
> > 
> > 
> > On Apr 29, 2005, at 11:05 AM, jcs6a50 wrote:
> > 
> > > All,
> > >
> > > Has anyone had trouble getting ChemEquil to behave?  I am
running
> a
> > > simple equilibrium problem with Ideal gases (and GRI3.0).  I
want
> to
> > > compute equilibrium solutions for a range of stoichiometries and
> > > various enthalpies.
> > >
> > > At adiabatic enthalpies, things work fine.  However, as I
> decrease the
> > > enthalpy further from the adiabatic value, ChemEquil hangs in
> > > ChemEquil::setInitialMoles inside the call to simplx_.  It gets
> stuck
> > > in an infinite loop (the L20-L30 loop).
> > >
> > > Any thoughts?
> > >
> > > James
> > >
> > >
